comment.body:
Thanks @oittaa, good improvement.

Looks like macOS needs `#include <sys/random.h>` for getentropy() to be available.  (The Linux manpage says that getentropy() can be imported from either unistd.h or sys/random.h.)
... Except that sys/random.h isn't present on older versions of Linux, in which case we seem to have to use unistd.h.  Sigh.

issue.title: Set version in configure, library, and algorithms
issue.body:
This adds an `alg_version` field to the `OQS_KEM` and `OQS_SIG` objects.  The intention for this field is as described in README.md:

> **Algorithm compatibility:** Unlike existing standardization cryptographic algorithms (SHA-2, SHA-3, PKCS\#1v1.5, nistp256, ...), post-quantum algorithms are under active development, and the mathematical algorithm of a cryptographic scheme may change: a particular name (e.g., "FrodoKEM-AES-640") may refer to different mathematical algorithms over time.  liboqs may update implementations as algorithms evolve.  Using our semantic versioning, versions with the same first two components ($X.Y.*$) will be interoperable.  But version $X.Y.Z$ and version $X.(Y+1).Z'$ may not be interoperable.  liboqs-reliant applications can check the `alg_version` member of the `OQS_KEM` data structure for each algorithm to obtain an identifier of the algorithm version used in a particular implementation; implementations returning the same `alg_version` for an algorithm will be interoperable.

This version is also recorded in the corresponding algorithm datasheet.

Where possible, a GitHub commit URL will serve as the version identifier for a particular algorithm.

comment.body:
@christianpaquin Can you provide the exact GitHub commit as the version for qTESLA and Picnic?  Insert at the `TODO` in:
- `docs/algorithms/sig_picnic.md`
- `docs/algorithms/sig_qtesla.md`
- `src/sig/picnic/sig_picnic.c`
- `src/sig/qtesla/sig_qtesla.c`

But version $X.Y.Z$ and version $X.(Y+1).Z'$ may not be interoperable.  liboqs-reliant applications can check the `alg_version` member of the `OQS_KEM` data structure for each algorithm to obtain an identifier of the algorithm version used in a particular implementation; implementations returning the same `alg_version` for an algorithm will be interoperable.

issue.title: Build issues on armv7l
issue.body:
### Environment
Platform: Raspberry Pi 3B
OS: Raspbian Stretch 9.4 armv7l
GCC 6.3.0 20170516 (Raspbian 6.3.0-18+rpi1+deb9u1)
GNU Make 4.1
autoconf/stable,now 2.69-10
automake/stable,now 1:1.15-6
git/stable,now 1:2.11.0-3+deb9u4
libssl-dev/stable,now 1.1.0f-3+deb9u2
libtool/stable,now 2.4.6-2
openssl/stable,now 1.1.0f-3+deb9u2
zlib1g-dev/stable,now 1:1.2.8.dfsg-5

### Steps to reproduce:
`git clone -b master --single-branch https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs.git`
`cd liboqs`
`autoreconf -i`
`./configure --prefix=<path-to-install-liboqs> --with-pic=yes`
`make`

### Issues
Using the instructions on the README, building on armv7l yields two main issues:

1.  AES and SSE2 gcc flags are included
`gcc: error: unrecognized command line option ‘-maes’; did you mean ‘-mapcs’?`
`gcc: error: unrecognized command line option ‘-msse2’`
Almost all makefiles return this error when running make.


2. The architecture is not recognized (I think), giving unsupported architecture warnings when building. (Possibly causing also 1?).
`config.h:52:2: error: #error -- "Unsupported ARCHITECTURE"`
` #error-- "Unsupported ARCHITECTURE"`



### Quick fixes
- For 1:
Removing all AES and SSE2 flags on all Makefiles:
`for file in $(find . -name Makefile); do sed -i -e 's/-maes -msse2//g' $file; done`

- For 2:
Removing the `#else` clause in the preprocessor, in `src/kem/frodokem/config.h`:
`sed -i -z 's/#else\n#error-- "Unsupported ARCHITECTURE"//g' src/kem/frodokem/config.h`

Applying both quick fixes above results in a successful build. Have not tested further.

Am I missing some steps or forgetting to set environment variables to properly configure the build?

comment.body:
Hi Angel, thanks for reporting this.  I'd like to fix this but may not be able to get to it for a few days.  

The quick fix of removing all AES and SSE2 flags isn't what we'd want to do, instead we'd have to figure out how to get autoconf CPU detection features in config/cpu\_features.m4 to set the appropriate compilation flags.

As well, if we're going to make ARM a target platform, I'd like to have a continuous integration environment for it.  Do you have any experience with that?
My colleague tested the build. This is ready for merge.

issue.title: Set version in configure, library, and algorithms
issue.body:
This adds an `alg_version` field to the `OQS_KEM` and `OQS_SIG` objects.  The intention for this field is as described in README.md:

> **Algorithm compatibility:** Unlike existing standardization cryptographic algorithms (SHA-2, SHA-3, PKCS\#1v1.5, nistp256, ...), post-quantum algorithms are under active development, and the mathematical algorithm of a cryptographic scheme may change: a particular name (e.g., "FrodoKEM-AES-640") may refer to different mathematical algorithms over time.  liboqs may update implementations as algorithms evolve.  Using our semantic versioning, versions with the same first two components ($X.Y.*$) will be interoperable.  But version $X.Y.Z$ and version $X.(Y+1).Z'$ may not be interoperable.  liboqs-reliant applications can check the `alg_version` member of the `OQS_KEM` data structure for each algorithm to obtain an identifier of the algorithm version used in a particular implementation; implementations returning the same `alg_version` for an algorithm will be interoperable.

This version is also recorded in the corresponding algorithm datasheet.

Where possible, a GitHub commit URL will serve as the version identifier for a particular algorithm.

comment.body: The way I understand semantic version is that 1.Y.Z and 1.A.B should be *binary* compatible, meaning they have the same binary API.  My sentence above was meant to say that cryptographic algorithms in 1.Y.Z and 1.A.B may not be algorithmically interoperable, meaning that Frodo in 1.Y.Z may produce incompatible ciphertexts with Frodo in 1.A.B.  But Frodo in 1.Y.Z would produce compatible ciphertexts with Frodo in 1.Y.W.

issue.title: Set version in configure, library, and algorithms

> **Algorithm compatibility:** Unlike existing standardization cryptographic algorithms (SHA-2, SHA-3, PKCS\#1v1.5, nistp256, ...), post-quantum algorithms are under active development, and the mathematical algorithm of a cryptographic scheme may change: a particular name (e.g., "FrodoKEM-AES-640") may refer to different mathematical algorithms over time.  liboqs may update implementations as algorithms evolve.  Using our semantic versioning, versions with the same first two components ($X.Y.*$) will be interoperable.  But version $X.Y.Z$ and version $X.(Y+1).Z'$ may not be interoperable.  liboqs-reliant applications can check the `alg_version` member of the `OQS_KEM` data structure for each algorithm to obtain an identifier of the algorithm version used in a particular implementation; implementations returning the same `alg_version` for an algorithm will be interoperable.

Where possible, a GitHub commit URL will serve as the version identifier for a particular algorithm.

comment.body:
I think we still want to maintain the existing semantics of semantic
versioning.

Because the way we are doing is hacking semantic versioning to accommodate
algorithm versioning.

Probably we should augment the scheme to introduce algorithm version such
that semantic versioning works as such.

For e.g.

X.Y.Z.A

X - algorithm version number
The rest is the default semantic versioning.
Once every thing stabilized we discard X and still be semantic version
compatible.

wrote:
